description: A unique identifier maintained by an authoritative database that represents a genetic variation. E.g. 20:2447955..2447958c>g
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity

The regular and simultaneous occurrence of alternative nucleotide sequences at equivalent locations of the genetic material among individuals of a single interbreeding population that are not maintained by recurrent mutation. Polymorphisms may range in size from single nucleotide to large nucleotide sequence variation visible at the chromosomal level. e.g. SNP
E.g. GRCh37. In Beacon, this is the assembly ID
A centrally registered identifier symbol that specifies an individual sequence record in a public sequence repository and used as a basis for comparison against another sequence. E.g. 11

A structure found in the nucleus of human cells that is comprised of a strand of linearized double-stranded DNA plus proteins that package the DNA in a condensed coil form and regulate chromosomal function. In beacon, this is the refSeqId / reference name
An extended part of a chromosome representing a term of convenience in order to hierarchically organize morphologically defined chromosome features: chromosome > arm > region > band > sub-band.
The starting position of a sequence feature or interval. E.g. 2447955
The ending position of a sequence feature or interval. E.g. 2447955
An allele whose sequence matches what is consdiered to be the reference sequence at that location in the genome.
Any allele of a variant which is not the in the reference genome currently being studied. The alternative allele is not necessarily the minor allele.
Single-stranded DNA that is complementary to messenger RNA or DNA that has been synthesized from messenger RNA by reverse transcriptase.
A reference to one or more processes (i.e., variant interpretations) where a variant was used
